newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ JULY FOOD PRICES UP MORE THAN ECONOMISTS F/CAST.
newsitem.headline: NZ JULY FOOD PRICES UP MORE THAN ECONOMISTS F/CAST.

text.p: New Zealand food prices rose 0.8 percent in July and were 2.7 percent higher than July 1996, Statistics New Zealand (SNZ) said on Wednesday.
Economists polled by Reuters had expected on average a 0.1 percent rise in the Food Price Index in July, for a 1.93 percent rise in the year ended July.
However, they also noted the monthly FPI was a volatile series.

SNZ said the July FPI rise was mainly driven by a 2.6 percent rise in the prices of fruit and vegetables, with cauliflower and broccoli recording the most significant increases. Fruit and vegetable prices are now 3.2 percent higher than a year ago.
SNZ said that excluding the volatile fresh fruit and vegetable sub-group, the Food Price Index rose 0.5 percent in July.
The price of groceries rose 0.7 percent in July and 2.5 percent in the year.

Meat, fish and poultry prices also rose 0.7 percent in the month, mainly driven by higher prices for mince, steak and pork. The meat, fish and poultry sub-group is now 4.3 percent higher than in July 1996.
Prices for restaurants and ready-to-eat food recorded no change in July, but were up 1.7 percent on a year ago.
SNZ said Timaru recorded the largest rise in food prices (up 1.2 percent), while Invercargill recorded the only fall down 0.7 percent).
Overall, North Island centres recorded an increase of 0.8 percent, while in the South Island the rise was 0.3 percent.
